ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge of multivariable calculus theories and integration techniques.
I furthered my abilities from Calc II and learned about vector fields.
I learned about multivarible integrals, divergence, gradient, and curl, and different ways to solve work and flux integrals.
Deepens my knowledge of Multivariable calculus.
I developed my understanding of multivariate calculus, by understanding the relationship between different theorems and techniques and looking at how these may be applied into a practical setting.
I learned a lot of new math skills and concepts.

I learned the basic applications of multivariable calculus. More importantly, the course served as an introduction to college learning as opposed to the more heavily guided high school math that I took.
Calc 3 techniques, as well as a study/organization strategies.

I felt greatly challenged in this course to apply the lectures to the problem sets, so my greatest insight was probably developing greater mathematical tuition in how to solve different problems and what methods are most appropriate when (especially with line integrals and surface integrals).
Multivariable calculus, skills in integration, functions in 3d spaces.
By taking this course, I developed my math skills and learned how to effectively study new material.
I learned the fundamentals of multivariable calculus which are essential to many areas of stem. I also improved my problem solving skills.
Calculus; Thinking about math in multiple dimensions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Well-organized. The concepts are arranged in such a way that each week builds on a previous one, and the instructors relate new concepts to familiar old ones. 

Weaknesses: Paced at a breakneck speed, but there's not really an easy way to slow down when there's so much to cover. I took the final yesterday and felt it was dramatically harder than either of the midterms, any of the psets, and any of the quizzes.
The course was structured and predictable in its expectations (psets, pre-class videos), but could be improved through more practice resources.

I think the course is very thorough in teaching every theorem and when to use it. The flow chart that connects all of the concepts we had been learning together through work and flux that we received at the end seemed like one of the most important concepts in the class and I wish I had received it earlier, so I could familiarize myself with it more before the final exam.
Not taught well
Lots of opportunities to practice problems

The course was taught in a good order, and it felt as though each lesson built from the last, with a nice summary at the end. To improve, a more intuitive definition towards the start of the course could be given of what a line integral actually represents.
I do not see many weaknesses of this course. The strengths of the course are that it was very interesting and my professor did a great job teaching it.

The strength of the course lies in the large amount of supplementary resources available to students. Things like Ximera were very helpful during the course. The large number of peer tutor hours was also helpful. The course was not the most captivating in terms of material, but that's not the goal of the course. It's hard to improve a course that does its job of teaching computational methods.
More problems in class, or supplementary worksheets would help. Review sessions often times didn't cover all the material.
The lecture material moves quite quickly, due to the expectation of having watched the lecture videos beforehand.

Strengths of this class are how there are plenty of peer and professor office hours to help with questions on the psets and the small class sizes. Weaknesses are not doing enough problems in the lectures. Rather, we just went over what the textbook said (even though we had read it before) and did not get to many examples.

Like most mathematics and yale courses in general, I feel that the 120 course moves too fast. Well-prepared curriculums and subject matter suffer from a severe time crunch, which drives students' grades down, which in turn is compensated for by well-documented grade inflation. Overall, the quality of the learning goes down, and the current trends do not show this changing any time soon.
Sometimes I felt like the classes were a little bit unhelpful, so I think this course could be improved by organizing the classes more effectively (eg. doing more practice problems)
This class does a poor job of ensuring that all sections are learning the same thing at the same level.

I thought a strength was the recorded modules because they helped in learning new things. A weakness was that the actual in-class sessions felt more like reviewing what was said in the videos and doing example problems. I think re-teaching the content would have been more helpful.

Strengths: Organized curriculum
Weaknesses: I wish there could be more practice material/exam prep

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, unless you have to. That being said, I feel that it is a great option if you need multivariable calc.
I would recommend this course because its a common prerequisite for other courses.
Not unless required
Yes, taught well and organized
Absolutely, it is a great (and necessary, depending on your major) intro to multivariate calc, that has clearly been well thought out and is taught well.
Yes, it is a great course if you want to learn a lot about multivariable calculus.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. Although it is not necessarily the interesting of classes (the problems are aimed towards teaching computation), it is valuable for other classes. Having a solid foundation for multivariable calculus is very important going forward, especially for physics and other stem majors.
Yes. The class offers a comprehensive introduction to Multivariable Calculus, and the course content is well-organized to facilitate student learning.

I would because I think that expanding upon the AP Calculus AB/BC skills in three dimensions is very eye-opening and a great extension of learning. It was also a challenging but rewarding class, and I enjoyed many of the subjects of study.
Yes! Math is cool, 120 is a good class to take if you are not otherwise very busy in a semester.
I would only recommend this course to someone who enjoys math and would like to challenge themselves.
Yes, I think that overall, the class was organized well, and that multivariable calculus is an essential skill for people interested in STEM.
Yes, multivariable calculus was an enjoyable course and there was a lot of opportunities to receive support.
